description: Assesses ability to use evidence effectively in persuasive writing

levels.4: Evidence is specific, credible, and directly supports each claim
levels.3: Evidence is relevant and supports most claims
levels.2: Evidence is vague, weak, or only loosely connected to claims
levels.1: No real evidence; relies on unsupported opinions

feedback_stems.strength: Your evidence was strong and convincing, especially
feedback_stems.growth: Use specific facts, statistics, or expert opinions to strengthen your evidence

levels.4: Uses multiple types of evidence (facts, examples, anecdotes, expert opinions)
levels.3: Uses at least two types of evidence
levels.2: Relies on only one type of evidence

feedback_stems.strength: You used different types of evidence including
feedback_stems.growth: Mix up your evidence—try facts, examples, and stories to convince different readers

levels.4: Evidence is introduced, presented, and explained; reader sees the connection to the argument
levels.3: Evidence is connected to the argument with some explanation
levels.2: Evidence is dropped in without explanation

feedback_stems.strength: You explained how your evidence supports your argument, like when
feedback_stems.growth: After giving evidence, always explain WHY it proves your point

levels.4: Sources are credible and appropriate for the argument
levels.2: Sources are questionable or not identified
levels.1: No sources mentioned or sources are unreliable

feedback_stems.strength: You used credible sources to back up your claims
feedback_stems.growth: Tell readers where your evidence comes from—credible sources make arguments stronger
